title: Kenny Jackett faced with defensive dilemma
text:
Tweet 
The Wolves head coach will no doubt have breathed a huge sigh of relief the fractured metatarsal in the defender’s left foot will not require surgery, which would have kept him out of action until at least the New Year. 
But by the same token, he still faces a tricky four-to-six-week period while Ebanks-Landell allows the injury to heal. 
Since the return of captain Danny Batth to fitness, the 22-year-old has for the past few weeks represented the main back-up to a centre-backs unit already considerably thinned by the deadline-day departure of Richard Stearman to Fulham. Now, there is no room for error. What do you think? Log in and start commenting 
Quite how Jackett addresses the problem remains to be seen. While hinting he will only move in the transfer market should anything befall the current first-choice pairing of Batth and Kortney Hause, he must surely be tempted to bring another body on board for what will be a hectic spell of six games in the space of three weeks before the next international break. 
That would avoid moving too many pieces of a back four he believes has begun to find its balance in recent weeks, symbolised by the back-to-back clean sheets. 
Dominic Iorfa, at right-back, has been a key component and while the 20-year-old is a definite option as centre-back cover, having played there as a youngster, he is one Jackett is loathed to use. Dominic Iorfa steps out for England training (picture courtesy of @england) 
“Dominic is someone who could play centre-back but it would be my preference to keep him on the right and keep him developing there,” explained Jackett. “For young players, if they move positions too many times I don’t think it particularly helps them. 
“If you move too many times I don’t think you ever really settle down and learn one position. Dominic is in that area. 
“I personally feel when Dominic and Kortney are at full-back, though, the presence of our back four is very good, I can tell both are learning those positions. 
“It does not quite look right. In recent games, with Iorfa playing right-back and Kortney playing left centre-back, we look better balanced.” 
Central defence is not Jackett’s only concern – with a lack of like-for-like cover at left-back behind Scott Golbourne. Should the latter suffer any misfortune, Matt Doherty and Sylvain Deslandes remain the likely replacements with the head coach reluctant to move Hause from a central position. 
“The season throws these things up and as a club and as a team we have to cope,” said Jackett of Ebanks-Landell’s injury.
